topic.title: HPE Helion Development Platform 2.0: Release Notes

body.note: The process for upgrading HPE Helion OpenStack to version 2.1 requires a reboot which may prevent core HPE Helion Development Platform services from restarting. If your environment relies on HPE Helion Development Platform, please see Upgrading HPE Helion Open Stack to v2.1 for information on how to restart Helion Development Platform services.
body.p: The following release notes are for the HPE Helion Development Platform 2.0 released in November, 2015. We hope you enjoy the release!

section.title: In This Release:
section.p: HPE Helion Development Platform is comprised of the following services:

section.title: What's New
section.p: This release contains key functionality to make building and deploying cloud native apps easier and faster for our customers.

ul.li: Enterprises can deploy applications packaged as Docker containers into a managed Cloud Foundry-based Platform-as-a-Service (PaaS).

This release includes the new HPE Helion Code Engine - a continuous integration/continuous delivery (CI/CD) toolchain for automating the build/test/deploy workflow to help modernize the development experience.
Further integrating IaaS + PaaS, the Helion Development Platform Database Service offers support for clustered MySQL, MongoDB, and Redis.
The Database Service also includes a technical preview of Vertica.
The Messaging Broker Service supports RabbitMQ cluster provisioning.
Monitoring alerts available through Monasca for the Messaging Broker Service and the Database Service.
Improved documentation with targeted search and new user feedback link.

dlentry.dt: For HPE Helion Development Platform 2.0, the Marketplace Service has been deprecated.
dlentry.dd: The Vertica instance that was offered in the Marketplace has been replaced by the Vertica Technical Preview in the Database Service.

dlentry.dt: Multiple Syntax Errors in Python pip Install Output
dlentry.dd: Installing a Python package also installs any required dependencies. This may generate several syntax warnings inline as the install occurs. This is expected behavior, and unless the output of the pip install reflects a fatal error, the install is still considered "clean".

dlentry.dt: Create Clusters with Horizon or cf-mgmt Tool Only
dlentry.dd: Use only the Horizon UI or the cf-mgmt command line tool to create ALS clusters. Using kato node attach or other methods are unsupported and will not function properly.

dlentry.dt: Multiple Admin Password Prompts During Patch
dlentry.dd: When patching, the admin will be prompted for the password at least once and usually multiple times. This is a known issue.

dlentry.dt: Disk Allocation Min/Max for helion push --disk
dlentry.dd: The application disk reservation setting has a minimum value of 512 MB and a maximum of 2 GB. This is a per-instance limit.

dlentry.dt: Cluster Creation Fails, Log File Contains EOF Error
dlentry.dd: When creating a new ALS cluster, the creation fails. The /tmp/als_installer.txt logfile, located on the constructor VM, contains EOF errors. To fix this error, open the configuration management tool and enter cf-mgmt --disable-connection-reuse true. This setting ensures a new HTTP connection every time a request is made.

dlentry.dt: Cluster Creation Fails with "Disambiguate Network" Error
dlentry.dd:
Creating a cluster fails and the following error message is received: validating 'Network' failed, reason: More than one external network, disambiguate with external-network-name or external-network-id If an environment has multiple external networks, cluster creation may require a specific identifier to determine which to use.
Determine which network you wish to use. Either use Horizon to view the entire list or use a command line argument such as neutron net-list
Then pass that external network's name or id using the configuration management tool as follows: cf-mgmt cc --external​-network-n​ame <mynetworkName>cf-mgmt cc --external​-network-id <mynetworkID>

dlentry.dt: Creating an ALS cluster results in error: 413 Request Entity Too Large
dlentry.dd:
When using the cf-mgmt tool, cluster creation fails because the payload sent to OpenStack to boot a new instance was too large. This is caused by including certificates in the payload. To fix this, skip SSL validation or use Horizon to create the cluster instead.
Launch the cf-mgmt tool.
Add the --skip-ssl-validation parameter prior to the cluster creation command. cf-mgmt --skip-ssl-validation create-cluster [command options] [arguments...]

dlentry.dt: UTM or Gateway Firewalls
dlentry.dd: UTM (Unified Threat Management) or Gateway firewalls may interfere with upgrades, patches, or normal application staging if they are configured to inspect all HTTP(S) traffic between ALS nodes and upstream package repositories. See the full documentation for a detailed explanation and suggested solutions.

dlentry.dt: Harbor (Port Service) Node Configuration
dlentry.dd: The optional Harbor TCP/UDP port service must be set up on a node with a public network interface if you wish to enable port forwarding for user applications. The security group or firewall settings for this node should make the configured port range accessible publicly.

dlentry.dt: No option to reset password on Vertica Preview instance on Horizon
dlentry.dd: Vertica clusters can be accessed via credentials obtained by enabling root, either Horizon or the Trove CLI. Single node Vertica instances must have root enabled through the Trove CLI, as this action is not in Horizon.
Example: trove root-enable <instance>

dlentry.dt: Searching for log entries returns API KEY ERROR: Missing
dlentry.dd: The current Vertica Management Console release has a known issue where searching for Vertica log entries may result in an API key being requested. As a workaround, it is suggested to access Vertica event data directly through the database's ACTIVE_EVENTS, QUERY_EVENTS and QUERY_REQUESTS tables, as described in Managing a Vertica Cluster from the Management Console.

dlentry.dt: "Stack trove in status ROLLBACK_COMPLETE" message when Database as a Server installation fails
dlentry.dd: The installation process may display a ROLLBACK_COMPLETE when installation fails. This may look like the following: .devplatform)stack@redwood:~$ openstack --os-cloud mycloud hdpi database install --path cow2_2.0.0.31.csu dbaas-qcow2_2.0.0.31.csu is already downloaded dbaas-qcow2_2.0.0.31.csu is already (installed) Disabling SSL Features for databaseervice Launching stack... Stack trove creating Stack trove in status ROLLBACK_COMPLETE UI installed for database Create service endpoint for service database Completed installing database .devplatform)stack@redwood:~$

dlentry.dt: “mysql cluster 5.5” listed as option in Launch Instance dialog
dlentry.dd: When Launch Instance is selected in the Project -> Database -> Instances panel in Horizon, a Datastore option of mysql-cluster version 5.5 is displayed. Selecting this option creates a standard mysql cluster.

dlentry.dt: Workaround for installations with TLS (Transport Layer Security) disabled

dd.p: When TLS is disabled, there is no file to specify for the ephemeral_ca_cert file. Instead, an empty file needs to be specified, and the endpoint URLs must be changed from https to http:

ol.li: in ~/.config/openstack/clouds.yaml database section, specify: database: ephemeral_ca_cert: /tmp/empty-file

dd.p: Next, after installing the Database Service on the Lifecycle Manager (deployer) node, do the following:

ol.li: List database endpoints: stack@ma-ccp-c0-m1-mgmt:~$ openstack endpoint list | grep database 6962276204934327a09501c0e44fca08 region1 database database True internal https://10.241.127.69:8779/v1.0/$(tenant_id)s a042121327374301b5106bec388e6146 region1 database database True admin https://10.241.127.69:8779/v1.0/$(tenant_id)s c02dbcc653824bd4baa7ac2bfe1d4fab region1 database database True public https://10.241.127.69:8779/v1.0/$(tenant_id)s

Modify the endpoint URLs: stack@ma-ccp-c0-m1-mgmt:~$ openstack endpoint set --url 'http://10.241.127.69:8779/v1.0/$(tenant_id)s' 6962276204934327a09501c0e44fca08 stack@ma-ccp-c0-m1-mgmt:~$ openstack endpoint set --url 'http://10.241.127.69:8779/v1.0/$(tenant_id)s' a042121327374301b5106bec388e6146 stack@ma-ccp-c0-m1-mgmt:~$ openstack endpoint set --url 'http://10.241.127.69:8779/v1.0/$(tenant_id)s' c02dbcc653824bd4baa7ac2bfe1d4fab

Verify the endpoint URLs: stack@ma-ccp-c0-m1-mgmt:~$ openstack endpoint list | grep database 6962276204934327a09501c0e44fca08 region1 database database True internal http://10.241.127.69:8779/v1.0/s a042121327374301b5106bec388e6146 region1 database database True admin http://10.241.127.69:8779/v1.0/s c02dbcc653824bd4baa7ac2bfe1d4fab region1 database database True public http://10.241.127.69:8779/v1.0/s

dlentry.dt: Enabling Monasca Monitoring for the Database Service
dlentry.dd:
The following instructions will enable the Monasca agent on the DBaaS control plane. These instructions assume that you have permission to SSH into the control plane.
Secure copy the following packages onto each control plane instance:Six-1.9.0 Python-keystoneclient-0.10.1 Oslo.i18n-1.5.0 Pbr-0.11.0 Oslo.utils-1.4.0 Oslo.serialization-1.4.0 Stevedore-1.3.0 Oslo.config-1.3.0
Use pip install to install the packages in the order listed.
Run bash /etc/monasca/start-monasca to set up the Monasca agent on that machine.

dlentry.dt: Manual Creation of the Database Endpoint
dlentry.dd: If the installer fails to create the database endpoint at the end of the installation, run the following commands to manually create one. You will need to supply the IP address of the VIP.$ openstack service create --name database database $ openstack endpoint create database admin 'http://<public-VIP-IP-address>:8779/v1.0/$(tenant_id)s' $ openstack endpoint create database internal 'http://<public-VIP-IP-address>:8779/v1.0/$(tenant_id)s' $ openstack endpoint create database public 'http://<public-VIP-IP-address>:8779/v1.0/$(tenant_id)s'

dlentry.dt: Redis Errors Appear in Horizon UI
dlentry.dd: In the Horizon UI, the Users and Databases tabs display errors for Redis instances. This is due to a bug in Horizon UI, and can be ignored. Functionality of Redis instances is not impacted by this UI problem.

dlentry.dt: Lack of Service Brokers for new Trove services
dlentry.dd: Connect Trove database instances using User Defined Services.

dlentry.dt: Alarms appear in "No Service Defined" Panel
dlentry.dd: If the Messaging Broker sends alarms for MySQL or Zookeeper, they appear in the "No Service Defined" panel, not the Messaging Broker Service panel. This is a known issue.

dlentry.dt: deployer_flavor Value Must Be Changed to 3 (Medium)
dlentry.dd: This setting is found in the Messaging Broker Service section of the clouds.yaml file. The value for the flavor ID to use for the deployer instance defaults to 4 (Large) but you must change this value to 3 (Medium) or installation cannot complete successfully. The value must be 3; no other value is valid. This is a known issue.
